ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A very solid knowledge of Chekhov's oeuvre, insights into critical trends past and present
I learnt a lot about how to approach a particular literary text (close-reading, contextual/inter-textual reading, etc.) and to critically appreciate the ambiguities of Chekhov's literary creation.

I learned a lot about Chekhov and his oeuvre, as well as the scholarship about him. I think that it is extremely important to have a course dedicated to one writer, because these courses allow to really appreciate and understand an author. Although I know it is rare nowadays to have this type of courses, I was very happy to participate in it.
Thorough overview of Chekhov and his works. Different theoretical models for approaching his work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: selection of readings (primary and secondary), ethical dimension of reading, professor's enthusiasm Weaknesses: the weekly load was on the high side at times The course was excellent, it would be hard to improve.
To associate each week with a central theme of discussion is helpful and productive.
I loved the fact that we read different genres: including Sakhalin Island and dramas.
I would include paper presentations in the last two weeks of the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, wholeheartedly. Wonderful subject matter, excellent teaching, great discussions to be had that engage both mind and heart
I would. I think that Chekhov is an extremely important writer and any literature scholar should be familiar with his work.
Yes, it would be helpful to students in a variety of disciplines.
